newsitem.title: UK: Mideast crude tanker fixing steams on, rates softer.
newsitem.headline: Mideast crude tanker fixing steams on, rates softer.

text.p: Crude tanker chartering in the all important Middle East Gulf market was good after the fair start to the week. But the rejuvenation did not herald a rise in rates, brokers said on Tuesday.
By mid-afternoon, three VLCCs had been seen, with two finding employment to the East. Shell's chartering of the Knock More at W47.5 was seen as typical of the Gulf-Singapore/East rates.
Brokers said VLCC trips to Japan were a touch softer at W55, off W2.5 from last done levels.
Vessels travelling to the West could command around W48.

Rates for 80,000 tonners going cross-Med fell fractionally to W95, as evidenced by OMV's chartering of the Frankopan travelling Libya-Trieste. But brokers said that as low as W92.5 had been seen done.
"There is an abundance of vessels in this region, with more returning this week. It is possible that rates may drop slightly lower," said an Italian broker.
In the inter-UKC sector rates ascended to W95, up W2.5 points, as tonnage availability tightened.
Two transatlantic trips were seen, with Statoil and J.P. Morgan both chartering vessels.
Caribbean rates for 70,000 tonners going upcoast-U.S. fell to W142.5 from W147.5, though as low as W140 was seen done.
The West African theatre saw rates rise for VLCC to W64-65 from W60 as charterers competed for thinning tonnage. Suezmax rates suffered as the bigger ships picked up business.
Fuel oil chartering in the UKC continued to see steady rates of around W210 on 25,000 tonners, the same level as in the Med.
UKC activity was focussed on the Baltic, with one shipping broker noting difficulty in finding a tanker for a north Spain pick-up.
